results.title: Machine tools and motions
results.brief_description: On-the-job pictures show how a worker’s strength is taxed by badly located and incorrectly designed controls on machine shop equipment. The following three principles are elaborated: 1. Locate the machine control so that the operator can maintain normal posture and is not required to work within a dangerous area. 2. Design controls so that unnecessary motions are eliminated from the operations cycle. 3. Design the controls so that necessary motions are within the normal work area.

results.title: Machine operation
results.creator_credit: United States. Navy and De Frenes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic typing”.
Demonstrates correct stroking at speeds ranging from 35 to 180 words per minute. Explains the functions of the various parts of the typewriter and demonstrates the use of these on various types of machines. Demonstrates how to attain correct touch for noiseless, manual, and electric machines.

results.title: Machine Gun Kelly
results.creator_credit: American International Pictures (AIP) and Roger Corman
results.brief_description: Loosely based on a real-life story, this 1930s depression-era gangster flick stars Charles Bronson in the titular role, as a sadistic killer. A bank robber leading a motley band, Kelly is goaded into more elaborate crime by his ambitious wife who craves media attention and basks in her husband’s notoriety. Alas, Kelly decides to hold the daughter of a wealthy industrialist for ransom. Things go badly when a fractious gang member seeks revenge on his leader. Despite its B-movie credentials, “Machine Gun Kelly” impresses as a claustrophobic crime drama, marking Corman’s move into big-league movie making.

results.title: Machine gun blues = Black rose of Harlem
results.creator_credit: Pacific Trust, Mike Elliott, Roger Corman and Fred Gallo
results.brief_description: Set in Harlem in 1931 during the era of depression, bootlegging, mobsters and smokey nightclubs where white patrons came to see black jazz singers. Also a time when the mafia were trying to move in on the nightclubs and assert their control over the black Americans, a time of violence and machine guns and death to those who dared to challenge “the boss”. Georgia Freeman (Cynda Williams), a black jazz singer and Johnny Verona (Nick Cassavetes) a white mobster who works for Costanza (Joe Viterelli), “the boss”, find themselves entangled in a fiery and passionate affair which eventually can only lead to disaster, especially when Johnny is already betrothed to Costanza’s daughter. When Costanza decides to take over the nightclub where Georgia sings, all hell breaks loose. Racial tension, dangerous liaisons, lots of action and a great jazz soundtrack with a cast including Lawrence Monoson, Richard Brooks, Garrett Morris, Richard T. Jones, Tony Burton and Maria Ford. Music produced by Paul di Franco.

results.title: Macedonia
results.creator_credit: General Secretariat of Press and Information of Greece and Giorgos Zervoulakos
results.brief_description: A history of Greek Macedonia from prehistoric times to the 19th Century. It covers the relationship between Macedonia and early Greece, the life of the greatest of all Macedonians, Alexander the Great, the Ottoman invasion and longterm occupation by the Turks and the 19th Century resistance to the invaders. It also retells the Greek myths and sources of contemporary folk dances in Macedonia.

results.title: Macbeth: the witches [study extract]
results.creator_credit: Grand Prize Productions and George Schaefer
results.brief_description: Act 1: Scene 1 - the witches foretell Macbeth’s future, on the heath, before Macbeth and MacDuff. Scene 111 - Macbeth is seen in the famous soliloquy scene. Stars Maurice Evans (Macbeth), Ian Bannen (Macduff), and Valerie Taylor, Anita Sharp Bolster and April Olrich (The Witches).

results.title: Macbeth: the politics of power
results.brief_description: An interpretation of characters. Are the witches goddesses of fate, wicked old hags, or figments of Macbeth’s imagination? How does Macbeth remain a tragic hero when he is portrayed as a brutal murderer? Is Duncan a wise monarch, or an arrogant, corrupt and senile old man? What is the relationship among the main characters?
